columns.text: In this problem, we are required to determine the current ratio, quick ratio, cash ratio, NWC to total assets ratio, debt-equity ratio, equity multiplier, total debt ratio and long-term debt ratio for Just Dew It Corporation.

## a. Current ratio

The Current ratio measures the ability of a company to pay its short-term obligations and is determined by dividing the current assets by the current liabilities.

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Current ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Current Assets}} {\text{Current Liabilities}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

To determine the current ratio for 2017:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Current ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Current Assets}} {\text{Current Liabilities}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$96,171} {\$64,628}\\ \\
&= \boxed{1.49}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the current ratio for 2017 is **1.49**.

To determine the current ratio for 2018:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Current ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Current Assets}} {\text{Current Liabilities}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$104,124} {\$69,060}\\ \\
&= \boxed{1.51}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the current ratio for 2018 is **1.51**.

## b. Quick ratio

This financial ratio shows if the company can meet its short-term obligations with its most liquid assets.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Quick ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Current Assets - Inventory}} {\text{Current Liabilities}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

To determine the quick ratio for 2017:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Quick ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Current Assets - Inventory}} {\text{Current Liabilities}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$96,171 - \$54,632} {\$64,628}\\ \\
&= \boxed{0.64}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the quick ratio for 2017 is **0.64**.

To determine the quick ratio for 2018:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Quick ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Current Assets - Inventory}} {\text{Current Liabilities}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$104,124 - \$57,204} {\$69,060}\\ \\
&= \boxed{0.68}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the quick ratio for 2018 is **0.68**.

## c. Cash ratio

This financial ratio shows if the company can meet its short-term obligations using only its cash and cash equivalents.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cash ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Cash + Marketable Securities}} {\text{Current Liabilities}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

To determine the cash ratio for 2017:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cash ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Cash + Marketable Securities}} {\text{Current Liabilities}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$ 12,157} {\$64,628}\\ \\
&= \boxed{0.19}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the cash ratio for 2017 is **0.19**.

To determine the cash ratio for 2018:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cash ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Cash + Marketable Securities}} {\text{Current Liabilities}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$14,105} {\$ 69,060}\\ \\
&= \boxed{0.20}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the cash ratio for 2018 is **0.20**.

## d. NWC to total assets ratio

This financial ratio compares the net liquid assets to the total assets of the company.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NWC}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Current Assets - Current Liabilities}} {\text{Total Assets}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

To determine the NWC to total assets ratio for 2017:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NWC}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Current Assets - Current Liabilities}} {\text{Total Assets}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$96,171 - \$64,628} {\$463,412}\\ \\
&= \boxed{0.0681}\\ \\
&= \boxed{6.81\%}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the NWC to total assets ratio for 2017 is **6.81%**.

To determine the NWC to total assets ratio for 2018:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{NWC}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Current Assets - Current Liabilities}} {\text{Total Assets}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$104,124- \$69,060} {\$479,954}\\ \\
&= \boxed{0.0731}\\ \\
&= \boxed{7.31\%}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the NWC to total assets ratio for 2018 is **7.31%**.

## e. Debt-equity ratio

The Debt-equity ratio compares a company's total debt to total equity and is determined by dividing the total liabilities by the total shareholders' equity.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Debt-equity ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Total Liabilities}} {\text{Total Shareholder's equity}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

To determine the debt-equity ratio or 2017:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Debt-equity ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Total Liabilities}} {\text{Total Shareholder's equity}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$64,628 + \$49,000} {\$349,784}\\ \\
&= \boxed{0.32}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the debt-equity ratio for 2017 is **0.32**.

To determine the debt-equity ratio or 2018:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Debt-equity ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Total Liabilities}} {\text{Total Shareholders' equity}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$69,060 + \$45,000} {\$365,894}\\ \\
&= \boxed{0.32}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the debt-equity ratio for 2018 is **0.32**.

## Equity multiplier

This financial ratio measures a portion of a company's assets that is financed by shareholders' equity.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Equity multiplier}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Total Assets}} {\text{Total Shareholders' Equity}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

To determine the equity multiplier for 2017:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Equity multiplier}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Total Assets}} {\text{Total Shareholders' Equity}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$463,412} {\$349,784}\\ \\
&= \boxed{1.32}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the equity multiplier for 2017 is **1.32**.

To determine the equity multiplier for 2018:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Equity multiplier}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Total Assets}} {\text{Total Shareholders' Equity}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$479,954} {\$365,894}\\ \\
&= \boxed{1.31}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the equity multiplier for 2018 is **1.31**.

## f. Total debt ratio 

This financial ratio measures the company's assets that are financed by debt.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Total debt ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Total Liabilities}} {\text{Total Assets}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

To determine the total debt ratio for 2017:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Total debt ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Total Liabilities}} {\text{Total Assets}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$64,628 + \$49,000} {\$463,412}\\ \\
&= \boxed{0.25}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the  total debt ratio for 2017 is **0.25**.

To determine the total debt ratio for 2018:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Total debt ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Total Liabilities}} {\text{Total Assets}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$69,060 + \$45,000} {\$479,954}\\ \\
&= \boxed{0.24}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the  total debt ratio for 2018 is **0.24**.

## Long-term debt ratio

This financial ratio shows the company's ability to pay for long-term debt.

The formula is denoted as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Long-term debt ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Long-term debt }} {\text{Shareholders' equity}}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

To determine the long-term debt ratio for 2017:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Long-term debt ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Long-term debt }} {\text{Shareholders' equity}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$49,000} {\$349,784}\\ \\
&= \boxed{0.14}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the long-term debt ratio for 2017 is **0.14**.

To determine the long-term debt ratio for 2018:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Long-term debt ratio}& =
 \dfrac{\text{Long-term debt }} {\text{Shareholders' equity}}\\ \\
& = \frac{\$45,000} {\$365,894}\\ \\
&= \boxed{0.12}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the long-term debt ratio for 2018 is **0.12**.
This problem requires us to calculate the different financial ratios of Just Drew It company for the years 2020 and 2021.

## Requirement A- Current Ratio
\
**Current ratio** is the measurement of the company's ability to pay its short-term debt, usually to suppliers and short-term creditors like banks.

Extracted from the balance sheet of Just Drew It are the following figures that will be used in the computation of the Current ratio. 

|Given |2020 |2021 | 
|--|--:|--:| 
|Total current assets |$115,413 |$130,155 | 
|Total current liabilities |$77,548 |$88,397 |

Below is the computation of the **current ratio for 2020**. 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Current ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Current asset}}{\text{Current Liabilities}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$115,413 }}{\text{\$77,548 }}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{1.49 times}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The entity has $1.49 of current assets for every $1 of current liabilities.

Below is the computation of the **current ratio for 2021**. 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Current ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Current asset}}{\text{Current Liabilities}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$130,155 }}{\text{\$88,397 }}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{1.47 times}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The entity has $1.47 of current assets for every $1 of current liabilities.

## Requirement b- Quick ratio
**Quick ratio** is similar to current ratio **except** that the inventories are excluded from the current assets. 
\
It is a liquidity ratio that measures the company's ability to pay its current obligations without the need to sell its inventories.

Extracted from the balance sheet of Just Drew It are the following figures that will be used in the computation of the Quick ratio

|Given |2020 |2021 | 
|--|--:|--:| 
|Total current assets |$115,413 |$130,155 | 
|Inventories| $65,567| $71,505|
|Total current liabilities |$77,548 |$88,397 |

Below is the computation of the **quick ratio for 2020**. 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Quick ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Current asset - Inventories}}{\text{Current Liabilities}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$115,413 - \$65,567 }}{\text{\$77,548 }}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{0.64 times}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The quick ratio is 0.64 times

Below is the computation of the **quick ratio for 2021**. 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Quick ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Current asset - Inventories}}{\text{Current Liabilities}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$130,155 - \$71,505 }}{\text{\$88,397 }}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{0.66 times}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The quick ratio is 0.66 times

## Requirement c- Cash ratio
**Cash ratio** is another liquidity measure that indicates the company's ability to cover its short-term obligation using cash and cash equivalent only.

Extracted from the balance sheet of Just Drew It are the following figures that will be used in the computation of the Cash ratio

|Given |2020 |2021 | 
|--|--:|--:| 
|Cash | $14,588| $17,631|
|Total current liabilities |$77,548 |$88,397 |

Below is the computation of the **cash ratio for 2020**. 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Cash}}{\text{Current Liabilities}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$14,588 }}{\text{\$77,548 }}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{0.19 times}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The cash ratio is 0.19 times

Below is the computation of the **cash ratio for 2021**. 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Cash}}{\text{Current Liabilities}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$17,631 }}{\text{\$88,397 }}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{0.20 times}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The cash ratio for 2021 is 0.20 times

## Requirement d- NWC to total assets
The **NWC or net working capital to total assets ratio** is another measurement of the short-term liquidity of the firm. 
\
It is calculated by subtracting the current liabilities from the current assets and dividing the result by the total asset.

The formula to calculate the NWC to total assets is as follows. 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NWC to total assets}&=\dfrac{\text{Current assets - Current liabilities}}{\text{Total assets}}\\[15pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Extracted from the balance sheet of Just Drew It are the following figures that will be used in the computation of the NWC to total assets.

|Given |2020 |2021 | 
|--|--:|--:| 
|Total current assets |$115,413 |$130,155 | 
|Total current liabilities |$77,548 |$88,397 | 
|Total Assets| $592,826| $628,576|

Below is the computation of the **NWC to total  assets for 2020**. 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NWC to total assets}&=\dfrac{\text{Current assets - Current liabilities}}{\text{Total assets}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$115,413 - \$77,548 }}{\text{\$592,826}}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{0.06 times}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The NWC to total assets for 2020 is 0.64 times.

Below is the computation of the **NWC to total  assets for 2021**. 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NWC to total assets}&=\dfrac{\text{Current assets - Current liabilities}}{\text{Total assets}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$130,155 - \$88,397 }}{\text{\$628,576}}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{0.07 times}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The NWC to total assets for 2021 is 0.07 times.

Extracted from the balance sheet of Just Drew It are the following figures that will be used in the computation of the debt to equity ratio and equity multiplier.

|Given |2020 |2021 | 
|--|--:|--:| 
|Total Assets| $592,826| $628,576|
|Total liabilities |$135,548 |$150,397| 
|Total equity|$457,278|$478,179|

## E.1
Below is the computation of the **Debt to equity ratio for 2020**.
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Debt to Equity ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Total debt}}{\text{Total equity}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$135,548 }}{\text{\$457,278}}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{0.30 times}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The debt to equity for 2020 is 0.30 times

Below is the computation of the **Debt to equity ratio for 2021**.
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Debt to Equity ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Total debt}}{\text{Total equity}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$150,397}}{\text{\$478,179}}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{0.31 times}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The debt to equity ratio for 2021 is 0.31 times

## E.2
Below is the computation of the **Equity multiplier for 2020**.
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equity multiplier}&=\dfrac{\text{Total asset}}{\text{Total equity}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$592,826}}{\text{\$457,278}}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{1.30 times}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The Equity multiplier for 2020 is 1.30 times.

Below is the computation of the **Equity multiplier for 2021**.
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equity multiplier}&=\dfrac{\text{Total asset}}{\text{Total equity}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$628,576}}{\text{\$478,179}}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{1.31 times}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The Equity multiplier for 2021 is 1.31 times

## Requirement f- (1.) Total debt ratio and (2.) Long term debt ratio
\
The **total debt ratio** also known as debt to asset ratio indicates the portion of the entity's total asset that is financed by the creditors
\
This is calculated using the following formula.
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total debt ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Total assets - Total Equity}}{\text{Total assets}}\\[15pt]
\end{aligned}$$

The **Long-term debt ratio** compares the amount of long-term debt to the entire worth of a company's total assets on its books. In other terms, it indicates a company's financial leverage.
\
It is calculated using the following formula. 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Long-term debt ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Long-term debt}}{\text{Long-term debt + Total equity}}\\[15pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Extracted from the balance sheet of Just Drew It are the following figures that will be used in the computation of the debt to equity ratio and equity multiplier.

|Given |2020 |2021 | 
|--|--:|--:| 
|Total Assets| $592,826| $628,576|
|Total equity|$457,278|$478,179| 
|Long-term liabilities |$58,000|$62,000|

## F.1
Below is the computation of the **Total debt ratio for 2020**.
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total debt ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Total assets - Total Equity}}{\text{Total assets}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$592,826 - \$457,278}}{\text{\$592,826}}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{0.23 times}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
The total debt ratio for 2020 is .23 times.

Below is the computation of the **Total debt ratio for 2021**.
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total debt ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Total assets - Total Equity}}{\text{Total assets}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$628,576- \$478,179}}{\text{\$628,576}}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{0.24 times}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
The total debt ratio for 2021 is .24 times.

## F.2
Below is the computation of the **Long-term debt ratio for 2020**.
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Long-term debt ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Long-term debt}}{\text{Long-term debt + Total equity}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$58,000}}{\text{\$58,000+ \$457,278}}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{0.113 times}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
The Long-term debt ratio for 2020 is.113 times.

Below is the computation of the **Long-term debt ratio for 2021**.
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Long-term debt ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Long-term debt}}{\text{Long-term debt + Total equity}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$62,000}}{\text{\$62,000+ \$478,179}}\\[15pt]
&=\textbf{0.115 times}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
The Long-term debt ratio for 2021 is.115 times.
